Message.Title: Who owns the Republican Party?
Message.Msg: The Heritage Foundation!!! (Reagan) In January 1981 Heritage published the Mandate for Leadership, a comprehensive report aimed at reducing the size of the federal government containing more than 2,000 specific suggestions to move the federal government in a conservative direction. The report was well received by the White House, and several of its authors went on to take positions in the Reagan administration.[8] Approximately 60% of the 2,000 proposals were implemented or initiated by the end of Reagan’s first year in office (H Bush) The Heritage Foundation remained an influential voice on domestic and foreign policy issues during President George H. W. Bush’s administration. It was a leading proponent of Operation Desert Storm against Iraq, and according to Frank Starr, head of the Baltimore Sun’s Washington bureau, the foundation’s studies, "laid much of the groundwork for Bush administration thinking" about post-Soviet foreign policy.[13] In domestic policy, the Bush administration agreed with six of the ten budget reforms contained in Mandate for Leadership III and included them in their 1990 budget proposal. (W Bush) Heritage has hosted many influential foreign and domestic political leaders since its founding, including Congressmen, U.S. Senators, foreign heads of state, and U.S. Presidents. On November 1, 2007, President George W. Bush visited Heritage to defend his appointment of Michael Mukasey to succeed Alberto Gonzales as Attorney General of the United States; Mukasey's nomination faced opposition in the U.S. Senate over the nominee's refusal to label the interrogation tactic of waterboarding as illegal.[18] Mukasey was confirmed and became Attorney General eight days later. Heritage Foundation is also a part of the Koch Foundation Associate Program.[50]
Except for one glaring problem, waly-the-kkkunt...that's not windoze 8. W8 is a dismal FAIL, and PC sales are falling off a cliff. FOAD, idiot.

"Kara Swisher at All Things D reports CEO Steve Ballmer is going announce a big reorganization of the company this Thursday. "As part of the reorg, Microsoft's earnings reports could be totally different. Swisher says Ballmer is considering mashing up the reporting of the company's divisions. There's probably never been another company in history that has lost that much money online."

"The U.S. Postal Service is a textbook example of a once-avowed Windows loyalist switching to Linux for purely technical reasons. While the Postal Service ran Windows NT on its servers until the bitter end, they then switched to using over 900 Linux clusters spread throughout the country for use in sorting the nation's bulk mail. They use technology from Pacific Northwest Software, who proudly explains in-depth the work it has done in switching the Postal Service to a Linux-based infrastructure." There. Message.Msg: win8 is just an operating system..... who gets worked up over an operating system?? so the new metro interface isn't everyone's cup of tea but it can be optioned off..... remember everyone having a cow when the ribbon was introduced ?.... the peanut gallery insisted that vista was a piece of poop and I still have PCs running it just fine..... the real future for the more mature investor is that a large enterprise needs tightly coupled hand shaking from the data center out thru all of the devices in the field - whether they be desktop, laptop, smart phone......and that is what Microsoft is going to deliver. Their support and marketing toward the small business & consumer is done via their web site info necessarily, and which in total is a very large business - this web-centric area of product information/support is bureacratic & extremely confusing and needs alot better execution.

Maybe you ought to think about digging a hole in the ground, lying down in it and shoving a revolver in your mouth to relieve your constant embarrassment for being so stupid. Message.Msg: that when IBM takes a hit, all the other extended DOW stocks are a "must buy" THAT DAY. that NFLX is a must buy any time the market rises never mind there is no barrier to entry, their content is poor and the P/E 600 with scant hope of growth into that level. that Amazon with it's untested model is a buy no matter the recent run if the overall market rises. That CMG is a 12 billion dollar taco stand. That the normal action after a sharp sell off of the market is to rise every day and dither, never retreat. that uncertainty in the market and economy no longer matter. This is a manipulation, folks, and Bernanke is going to run out of paper some day soon. You cannot continue to borrow $3 to earn $1 in a business and that does not change for a country, it just takes longer.
